content: This post is sort of a response to GunnyRet03's 9% Union BS thread. The following came across my desk this morning and I wanted to pass it along before it gets dropped from my screen. This is the reason and NOT Unions that is behind 80% of the problems. Gunny's statement of $15 vs. $35 per hour is disingenuous at best... Specifically if taken over to the Manufacturing Industrial sectors. Our crap is in the wind because all sectors that can be off-shored ARE being off-shored piecemeal. I am looking at a MAJOR Technology firm that is privately hiring the below FOR Indonesia. Now the High Technology sector has never been Unionized... yet they are permanently shedding jobs and positions even faster than the so called Unionized non-tech shops. Are you people just going to make the silly statement that it's because the American worker wants too much money for his/her services? If you do... please explain how THIS COUNTRY could ever hope to move forward if EVERYONE took a 90% pay cut? All across the board. Just for your information... no one here could even BEGIN to afford goods made in China even if you took a US wide 50% paycut. content: Art what does $1,000 USD buy in Pakistan. You seem to confuse our standard of living to be the same as theirs. I had a conversation with a BHL in college about what a shoe company paid its workers in China. He felt they should be making at least the $7.25/hr Illinois workers were getting. He could not see a difference between our two countries. I had one of the other grad students who was from China come over, because I was only spouting BS. I asked Quan how much rice he could buy out at the local Wal-Mart for $5. He said about 5lbs. How long will that last your family? About 4-6 days, because both he and his wife are not home on a consistant basis. I asked now how much rice, how long it will last, and how many people are you feeding? He said he could get at least a 50lbs sack, it would last 10-12 days, and the home had about 10 people living there.

content: quote: but there are places that if you wish to have an actual employment... you are forced to go Union... otherwise it is minimum wage for you. well sure. just like there are many many more places where you are "forced" to go non union and make minimum wage. quote: But this thread really isn't all that much about Unions The problem is, most companies these days aren't built up by the owner and then passed on to the family. They don't look for good workers who are loyal to the company and are then in turn loyal to them. It's all about the quick buck. a company years ago might find a new process and save a few bucks per product then lower the product price to increase sales. now a company will fire off its older more experienced workers to hire someone either less experienced or from overseas(or both) and instead of using that savings to build up the company, they use that to increase dividends(and that usually means their bonuses as well). combine that with a stock market that demands stocks to outpreform instead of being a steady strong company and you have todays current job market.

content: I dont blame Unions. They are and should be looking out for their members ( full disclosure: I worked for a union for 6 years, and know full well some of the bs that goes on there). However, when GM and Ford cannot produce a car for a profit then there is a problem. That problem stems from the unions having too much power with our politcal hacks, and the companies not standing up to the unions. What the unions need to understand is that if they drive the auto makers out of business then NO ONE has a job.
